mimes.text/plain: Unstructured notes on blocks and encodings
describes the meaning of a piece of data in the context of a learning task
For example, for supervised learning tasks, there is an input block and a target block and we want to learn to predict targets from inputs
Learning to predict a cat/dog label (
) is a supervised image classification task
A block is not a piece of data itself
Instead it describes the meaning of a piece of data in a context
That a piece of data is a block can be checked using
A piece of data for the
block above needs to be one of the labels, so
We can say that a data container is compatible with a learning task if every observation in it is a valid sample of the sample block of the learning task
The sample block for supervised tasks is
from a compatible data container implies that
This also means that any data stored in blocks must not depend on individual samples; we can store the names of possible classes inside the
block because they are the same across the whole dataset
We can use blocks to formalize the data processing pipeline
we want to create pairs of data

and instead we have an encoding step that transforms a sample into representations suitable to train a model on, i

but we cannot put raw images into a model and get out a class
Instead, the image is converted to an array that includes the color dimension and its values are normalized; and the class label is one
Hence to do training, we need a sample encoding function
, we have an input and want to use a trained model to predict a target, i
The model is again a mapping
, so we can build the transformation with an encoding step that encodes the input and a decoding step that takes the model output back into a target
In the classification example we have, written in blocks,
Where do we draw the line between model and data processing? In general, the encoding and decoding steps are
transformations, while the model is a
are reversible transformations that model the non
learnable parts (encoding and decoding) of the data pipeline
What an encoding does depends on what block is passed in
Most encodings only transform specific blocks
which take in the block and the data
The actual encoding and decoding takes in an additional context argument which can be specialized on to implement different behavior for e

summary(data) = "100×100 Array{RGB{Float64},2} with eltype ColorTypes.RGB{Float64}"
summary(encdata) = "100×100×3 Array{Float32, 3}"
Using an encoding to encode and then decode must be block
To see the resulting block of applying an encoding to a block, we can use

encodedblock(enc, Image{2}()) = FastAI.Vision.ImageTensor{2}(3)
decodedblock(enc, ImageTensor{2}(3)) = Image{2}()
to test these invariants to make sure an encoding is implemented properly for a specific block

This is overwritten for blocks for which
are implemented to indicate that the data is transformed
Encodings can be applied to tuples of blocks
The default behavior is to apply the encoding to each block separately
Applying a tuple of encodings will encode the data by applying one encoding after the other
When decoding, the order is reversed
creates a learning task from blocks and encodings
You define the sample block (recall for supervised tasks this is a tuple of input and target) and a sequence of encodings that are applied to all blocks

expects a sample and just runs the encodings over that, giving us an encoded input

mimes.text/markdown:
**`SupervisedTask` summary**

Learning task for the supervised task with input `Image{2}` and target `Mask{2, Int64}`. Compatible with `model`s that take in `Bounded{2, FastAI.Vision.ImageTensor{2}}` and output `Bounded{2, FastAI.OneHotTensor{2, Int64}}`.

Encoding a sample (`encodesample(task, context, sample)`) is done through the following encodings:

|               Encoding |              Name |                                 `blocks.input` |                                 `blocks.target` |
| ----------------------:| -----------------:| ----------------------------------------------:| -----------------------------------------------:|
|                        | `(input, target)` |                                     `Image{2}` |                                `Mask{2, Int64}` |
| `ProjectiveTransforms` |                   |                     **`Bounded{2, Image{2}}`** |                **`Bounded{2, Mask{2, Int64}}`** |
|   `ImagePreprocessing` |                   | **`Bounded{2, FastAI.Vision.ImageTensor{2}}`** |                                                 |
|               `OneHot` |          `(x, y)` |                                                | **`Bounded{2, FastAI.OneHotTensor{2, Int64}}`** |

mimes.text/plain: The above tables make it clear what happens during training (
takes in encodings and blocks directly and can be useful for building an understanding of how encodings apply to some blocks

|               Encoding |   Name |                                                |
|------------------------|--------|------------------------------------------------|
|                        |  Input | `Image{2}`                                     |
| `ProjectiveTransforms` |        | **`Bounded{2, Image{2}}`**                     |
|   `ImagePreprocessing` |        | **`Bounded{2, FastAI.Vision.ImageTensor{2}}`** |
|               `OneHot` | Output |                                                |
Since most encodings just operate on a small number of blocks and keep the rest unchanged, applying them to all blocks is usually not a problem
When it is because you want some encoding to apply to a specific block only, you can use
